reviewText: good product and service
This is a keeper, and a SHARE.
great DVD.
Fast Shipping and just as described

In my opinion, The Retirement Gamble is one of Frontline's most interesting documentaries, as well as one of it's most useful.  It's useful because it discusses investment wisdom, in contrast to market hype. So you can consider it a primer on stable, retirement funding. It  argues, persuasively, that low cost index funds as the long term best bet.

It also digs into the retirement systems of most Americans, specifically the larger than expected fees of 401(k)s and mutual funds by many in the financial services industry.  It discusses the incentives of many "financial advisers", a title that doesn't have a concrete definition.  It compares those with a fiduciary duty (fee based) to those who work on portfolio sales (commission).  This raises the important question, "Is this person compensated in a way that motivates them to look after 'my' interests?"

While not sensationalist, it's eye opening in its reporting that so many Americans are not property preparing retirement.  And of those that are saving well, many aren't aware of the array of fees and costs imposed on their retirement plans. It's not easy to find these costs.  As of my writing of this review, the retirement system is far from transparent.

I have ordered this DVD as I am a Baby Boomer myself and am curious. I am acquiring as much information as I possibly can but if what is implied in this DVD there very well become a revolution of sorts in the US and in other Western Countries. There seems to be  a danger implied that perhaps some of the funds will be taken to run a broken economy. If that transpires we may very well have the very first uprising in Modern History against against a free new world Govt. So sad but possible, for the sake of out Grandchildren let's hope this does not transpire.

Journalist tries to find the fees charged to his retirement savings, and is unable to tally the amounts due to hidden monthly charges: administrative, transaction (posting interest, dividends earned from savings), RMD required minimum distribution fees, charges for each stock bond fund each time a withdrawal is posted as it is spread across the entire account. He discovers many others' retirement accounts are gutted by fees because they did not LOOK at their statements carefully. And the did not ask the important questions "are you my fiduciary?" meaning "is the advice you give me for MY financial benefit, are there legal repercussions if the advice benefits YOU financially and NOT me?" hidden charges, fees, bonuses paid to the broker for pushing funds being sold by the brokerage. Many individuals interviewed for this documentary discovered that their savings was decimated by fees and they did not have what they thought they did for retirement. 1992 hardback, 1993 paperback [ASIN:B0040IDAB4 Your Money Or Your Life: Transforming Your Relationship With Money And Achieving Financial Independence] is Joe Dominguez' account of twice gaining and losing fortunes in the stock market, then inheriting $30,000 in the 1960s and deciding never to work again. He became financially independent by tracking every penny he spent, marking it on a graph each month. And tracking how much INCOME he received from his savings (interest, dividends, found penny on sidewalk). Over 5 years the two curves crossed, his expenditures equaled his income from savings. Others wanted to know how he accomplished this feat. Dominguez was not wealthy but he didn't need to work unless he wanted to. He gave lectures, always paying his own travel expenses, and donating his fees to a foundation which donated all profits each year to charitable organizations which he supported. Since he didn't want to work, and speaking is work, he wrote Your Money or Your Life and donated the profits to the foundation as well. PBS followed up with two specials Affluenza and Escape From Affluenza about the infectious quality of spending on unneeded, unwanted gazingus pins (stuff which doesn't contribute to quality of life, and subtracts from savings for retirement). One of my professors has a son and wife who are documented in Dominguez' book. Sadly Dominguez died of cancer. His book has been updated by someone else and I do not know that the profits of the new version of the book continue to flow to the charitable foundation Dominguez established as was true of the original 1992 hardback. I recommend the 1992 hardback or 1993 paperback first edition only. My question: are 401(k) fees justified? Does the advice improve my decision making? Improve the investment income on retirement savings? or just deplete the savings from my work? There is a saying that the health of the Japanese economy depends on the frugality of the Japanese housewife. In America 80% of spending decisions are made by the wife. What about the savings decisions? Other thoughtful resources National Geographic: Stress - Portrait of a Killer heart attack, stroke and disability among Baby Boomers The Caregiver Helpbook, Powerful Tools for Caregivers half of caregivers die before the one they care for due to stress, how to manage the mental, physical, emotional, social, spiritual and financial demands of caring for children and others [ASIN:9992074108 Your Money Or Your Life: Transforming Your Relationship With Money And Achieving Financial Independence] Joe Dominguez no one cares about you keeping your money than you do; if you don't pay attention to your finances someone else is willing to pay attention and perhaps take it away from you Simplify Your Life: 100 Ways to Slow Down and Enjoy the Things That Really Matter remove the minus sign gazingus pins, increase the plus sign meaningful things A Calendar of Wisdom: Daily Thoughts to Nourish the Soul, Written and Selected from the World's Sacred Texts Leo Tolstoy's sole reading for the last 5 years of his life Dhamma Brothers how to self soothe, decrease anger resentment vindictiveness revenge Departures our final responsibility to one another final thought How to Die in Oregon individuals allow us to follow their journey of suffering, decision making, their final moments as they try to create a life of meaning The Retirement Gamble is a shocking expose of the brokerage industry's decimating of retirement savings through hidden fees. 5 stars

If nothing else, the Wall St. crashes and taxpayer money theft of late have taught us there are many questionable, hidden practices being allowed at the expense of others. Nothing is sacred. People's retirement funds were enthusiastically and unethically stolen here and over seas. So where does one get useful, accurate information on saving for retirement, 401(k)'s, IRA's?  This Frontline expose, along with many others is an excellent start!

The information, interviews, explanations etc. are well done for everyone. I highly recommend this from young adults to the elderly! It is great to be intelligently informed about wise saving choices.

Eye-opening facts and critical advice for those needing to prepare for an affordable retirement--sadly, as this excellent documentary shows, for those who are not vigilant, well- informed, and planning ahead retirement will more myth than reality.

I viewed this episode with my wife, and at the age of 51 new we were in trouble as we approach retirement age.  Every employee needs to see this to appreciate where they are relative to their own personal future - and security.  Especially those who are coming into what they believe is the "middle class."
Great product
Worthy of watching.  Would recommend sharing information with family and friends.
The book was a gift for my husband he likes it
A very accurate presentation

Revealing and educational. Also see Frontline: Economic Meltdown and Frontline: The Untouchables , all are essential to understanding what happened and what might happen to your investments. An entertaining companion to these is The Big Short
It was one of the best programs I have watched in a long time! It tells you the truth about investing and saving for retirement,etc SHOCKING!!!!
worth viewing
Excellent documentary.  A must see for all who are waking up about their finances.  Go John Bogle!

Some very good information about finance and investing, but the reporter seems to wander aimlessly at times, getting side-tracked to a variety of subjects. Despite the lack of focus, The Retirement Gamble has some important information everyone should see, no matter what their age or financial situation.
Yeah, the bald-faced truth about the racket that is our highly promoted retirement plan in the United States.
